Awami League (AL) Banned Not polled as a direct option The ban removes the largest political force, fundamentally reshaping the contest.

The geopolitical pivot: India-Bangladesh relations in crisis





The historical record of BNP and JI: Security nightmare for India

BNP’s ‘Bangladesh first’ narrative

Jamaat’s hardcore ideological stance





How each outcome could affect India — three scenarios

1) A BNP-led government

2) JI-influence / Islamist coalition

3) NCP or reformist coalition

Conclusion — a bilateral relationship at an inflection point









The February 2026 Bangladeshi general election is no ordinary democratic exercise; it is a vote on the country’s political future and a crucial deciding point for India's regional security.The street-led "Monsoon Revolution" of August 2024, which ended the 15-year rule of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina, created a political vacuum that has fundamentally altered the domestic power structure and, by extension, the strategic equation with New Delhi.This vacuum, marked by the unprecedented exclusion of the country's most dominant party, leaves the field open to forces historically critical of India, signalling the end of the cosy, pro-India era and demanding a rapid re-evaluation of New Delhi’s policy towards its eastern neighbour.Bangladesh is not merely a neighbour; it is a geostrategic imperative for India, acting as the key bridge, market and security partner for the entire eastern subcontinent. The stability of Dhaka directly translates into the security of New Delhi.The strategic importance of the relationship is deeply understood by the public.As Dr Rehan, a physician and cultural activist, told TOI, "People of Bangladesh follow the India-Bangladesh relationship from political, economic and cultural aspects."This constant public scrutiny means any future government must prioritise visibly equitable outcomes in the bilateral relationship.The ousting of Sheikh Hasina was not merely a regime change in Dhaka but a collapse of a government sensitive to New Delhi’s concerns.A student movement that began in mid-2024 rapidly escalated into nationwide unrest. The protests, sparked by demands over quotas in public jobs and expanding to broader grievances, culminated in Hasina’s resignation on August 5, 2024 and her departure from the country amid violent clashes that left hundreds dead and thousands injured.Amid the accusations of foreign interference, the mass upheaval opened the door for an interim administration tasked with restoring order and arranging new elections, headed by Nobel laureate Muhammad Yunus, who emerged as a saviour amidst the political chaos.He became the ‘chief adviser’ of the interim government and started running the administration with the support of student leaders and advisers who emerged out of the revolution that ousted Hasina.Eventually, the unelected Yunus-led interim government decided to hold elections in February 2026 and to pursue legal and institutional reforms intended to reset Bangladesh’s political institutions.But in the months that followed, an administration headed by a personality that had the apparent support of democracy-loving and liberal countries, cancelled the Awami League’s registration — effectively barring it from contesting the next national vote.Citing the need for accountability for alleged crimes against humanity, the interim government—following amendments to the country's anti-terrorism laws—suspended the AL's registration and barred it from all political activities.“The ban on activities of this party is necessary to protect national security and sovereignty, ensure the safety of July Movement activists, and safeguard plaintiffs and witnesses of International Crimes Tribunal,” Shafiqul Alam, press secretary to chief adviser Muhammad Yunus, had said.Meanwhile, AL rejected the ban as "illegal and unconstitutional" and described the prosecution as politically motivated. “To ban the activities of the Awami League in Bangladesh means to exile the spirit, ideals, and core values of the Liberation War, and to empower the vulgar resurgence of anti-independence elements”, it said in a statement.The single most defining factor of the 2026 election is the ban on the Awami League (AL).This action removed the only consistently pro-India secular force, forcing its base to become the largest "swing" vote in the upcoming polls and fundamentally reshaping the electoral contest.Following Hasina’s convictionfor crimes against humanity and the death sentence handed down by the International Crimes Tribunal in November 2025, the matter of her continued exile in India has become the principal irritant in bilateral ties.AL, led for decades by Sheikh Hasina, had pursued a generally India-friendly foreign policy marked by cooperation on connectivity projects, cross-border security, trade liberalisation, and river and water-management dialogues.With the AL sidelined for now, three political forces have emerged as the most consequential contestants or kingmakers for the 2026 elections: the Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP), Jamaat-e-Islami (JI), and the National Citizen Party (NCP), the political vehicle that coalesced from the 2024 student movement.The BNP, long the principal opposition to the Awami League and which had boycotted the 2024 elections, has been rebuilding organisationally and publicly announcing candidate slates for large numbers of constituencies in 2025.Led by the family of Khaleda Zia and the returning Tarique Rahman, the BNP frames the election as a return to multi-party democracy and its core philosophy of "Bangladeshi Nationalism."The party is heavily capitalising on the popular "India Out" sentiment, positioning itself as the defender of national sovereignty against perceived external interference.As per the Dhaka Tribune, BNP nominated candidates for 237 seats on December 3. This indicates the party is preparing to contest the election vigorously after years of marginalisation.Its political rhetoric tends to emphasise national sovereignty and a tougher posture on perceived external interference — language that has historically produced a more cautious view of India than AL’s cooperative stance — while remaining capable of pragmatic engagement on trade and security where it sees mutual benefit.In a notable recent development, PM Modi publicly expressed concern and offered India's support for the critically ill BNP Chairperson Khaleda Zia.The BNP leadership formally responded with sincere gratitude for the gesture of goodwill, marking a rare and significant instance of political warmth between the historically adversarial forces, hinting at a potential for pragmatic diplomacy if the BNP wins.JI, Bangladesh’s largest Islamist party, was legally constrained for years but saw a major political reopening in 2025 when the Supreme Court removed bans that had kept it out of formal politics.That judicial change has allowed JI to prepare for electoral participation. Politically, JI’s worldview and historical memory of 1971 make it more likely to temper Dhaka’s closeness to New Delhi.There’s a possibility that a JI-influenced government could diversify Bangladesh’s external partnerships and be more open to Chinese or Pakistani outreach on infrastructure and defence.The ideological core of the religious right, Jamaat's comeback, is New Delhi's greatest immediate security concern.Its organisational strength, evidenced by its student wing, Islamic Chatra Shibir’s, surprising victory in the Dhaka University union polls in September 2025, makes it a potent force.Its public rhetoric attempts a diplomatic balance, but its hardline ideological base remains fundamentally anti-secular and historically anti-India.The NCP emerged from the 2024 student movement and positions itself as a reformist, youth-led alternative to Bangladesh’s old party duopoly.It is led by figures like Nahid Islam, who represent a quest for structural reform and an end to dynastic politics. He was in central role against the movement against Hasina. When an interim government took over under the leadership of Dr Muhammad Yunus after Hasina’s ouster, Nahid joined it as an adviser.In his inaugural speech as convener, Nahid clearly stated the party's guiding principle, asserting that there would be “no room for pro-India and Pakistan politics in Bangladesh,” signalling an unambiguous focus on "Bangladesh First."In the past, he has been sharply critical of New Delhi’s policy under the Awami League era, publicly accusing India of maintaining relations only with the ruling elite and ignoring the people of Bangladesh.With the AL neutralised, the battle for the 300-seat Jatiya Sangsad has boiled down to a contest between two established forces and one emergent youth movement.Recent surveys underscore the volatility of the new political environment.A nationwide poll conducted by the International Republican Institute (IRI) between September and October 2025 shows a remarkably tight contest among the remaining major players:The data points to two critical features: first, the BNP is the narrow frontrunner, galvanised by the return and political acquittal of its leadership, including former Prime Minister Khaleda Zia and her son Tarique Rahman.Second, the resurgence of Jamaat-e-Islami is significant; despite securing only 4.28% of the vote in the last free election in 2008, its support has surged following the lifting of the Hasina-era ban, reflecting a strong organisational structure and a rising tide of identity politics.Crucially, the margin separating the BNP and Jamaat is a mere four percentage points, a difference dwarfed by the 18% of voters who remain either undecided or unwilling to state their preference.This ambiguity means the election is highly prone to a major swing, potentially favouring the extremely well-organised Jamaat network.The greatest impact of the 2026 election is the looming rupture in bilateral ties with India. The long era of security-centric cooperation under Sheikh Hasina, which saw a crackdown on Indian separatist groups and immense growth in connectivity projects, is over.Under Hasina, the AL managed a pragmatic, cooperative relationship with India — enabling cross-border railway and road links, trade expansion, and security cooperation.AL’s suspension removes a known quantity from the table and raises uncertainty about continuity.The likely new power brokers have past records that raise red flags in New Delhi.The BNP-Jamaat Coalition (2001-2006) period was a security low point.The Khaleda Zia government was widely accused of sheltering anti-India terrorist groups, notably the ULFA and NDFB, reportedly allowing Bangladeshi soil to be used as a staging ground.The infamous 2004 Chittagong arms haul, in which a massive consignment of arms destined for Indian insurgents was intercepted, remains the clearest evidence of this policy.The party has often openly embraced the popular sentiment of the "India Out" campaign, which emerged from the belief that New Delhi actively supported Hasina's authoritarian rule.This sentiment runs deep among the youth, as validated by Tonmoy Saha Joy, who is a lecturer at Islamic University, Kushtia and has studied at ICCR, Dhaka, and told TOI that "Most young Bangladeshis now feel that India is not a good neighbour for them. There are some religious and geopolitical issues behind this."For BNP, the core foreign policy principle being promoted is "Bangladesh first," which means such as prioritising Dhaka’s interests in water sharing (Teesta River) and refusing to tolerate any "assault on our sovereignty" or "interference in our internal affairs."“In foreign policy, BNP’s guiding philosophy is ‘Bangladesh first.’ My people, my country, my sovereignty — everything else comes after safeguarding these interests,” BNP’s acting chairman and Zia’s son, Tarique Rahman, had said in an interview with BBC Bangla.He went further and said India had become "unpopular among the people of Bangladesh" for sheltering the ousted Hasina, adding that he must stand by his countrymen in this situation.Historically, Jamaat has been the most ideologically anti-India force in Bangladesh, primarily due to its religious and historical roots.Jamaat vehemently opposed Bangladesh's independence during the 1971 Liberation War, siding with the Pakistani military. Many of its top leaders were later executed for war crimes by the Hasina government's International Crimes Tribunal. This history makes the party fundamentally opposed to the secular, pro-India narrative of Bangladesh's founding.During the 2001-2006 coalition, Jamaat leaders in cabinet positions allegedly facilitated the growth of indigenous militant groups like Harkat-ul-Jihad-al-Islami (HuJI) and Jamaat-ul-Mujahideen Bangladesh (JMB), many of which had explicit anti-India agendas.However, since being unbanned and surging in popularity, Jamaat has attempted to soften its international image while its grassroots remain radicalised.In 2024, Jamaat Chief Shafiqur Rahman made efforts to call for a harmonious relations with India, claiming the party is not inherently anti-India and its focus is solely on Bangladesh's interests.“We view India as a close neighbour and believe in the importance of good relations with those who live near us”, he had said.He also advocated for a balanced foreign policy that engages all major global powers, including China and the US.Despite hinting at diplomatic language, Jamaat’s deep ideological roots are Islamist and fiercely nationalistic, raising concerns about the potential for renewed support for extremist elements.On many occasions, both the BNP, Jamaat have strongly urged New Delhi to reassess its approach to bilateral ties and refrain from interfering in Bangladesh's domestic affairs, a thinly veiled critique of India's past support for the Awami League.Below are three broad post-election scenarios and their likely implications for New Delhi.If BNP forms a government or leads a coalition without a dominant Islamist partner, expect a transactional relationship: cooperation on trade and security where interests align, but more insistence from Dhaka on sovereignty clauses, renegotiation of certain deals, and a more public-facing nationalist narrative.For India, this will require renewed diplomacy, quicker confidence-building measures, and clearer incentives for joint infrastructure projects.A government with strong JI influence could recalibrate Dhaka toward alternative partners. India could face slower progress on connectivity projects, a chill in high-level political warmth, and the need to guard against strategic encroachment by other powers.Delhi would need contingency plans for northeastern connectivity, expand people-to-people engagement, and strengthen defence and intelligence cooperation with like-minded regional partners.Although there’s a lower possibility for NCP or any other coalition to come to power this time. However, if this improbable forecast does come true, then a reformist, youth-led government could open new pathways for India-Bangladesh cooperation if it prioritises institutional stability, economic growth and connectivity.However, political inexperience and a crowded coalition could slow decision-making.Here, India can gain by offering capacity-building, development finance with clear transparency, and quick-win projects that visibly benefit ordinary citizens. Direct engagement with the Bangladeshi public, especially the youth, can help New Delhi to foster a trusting partnership.The 2026 election is not only a domestic contest for Bangladesh; it is a regional inflection that will influence trade corridors, security architectures and the balance of great-power influence in South Asia.This election will not merely install a new government; it will formalise Dhaka’s geopolitical pivot.The removal of the Awami League has eliminated India's reliable anchor in Dhaka, replacing it with a volatile political environment where the next government, whether led by the BNP or dominated by the influence of Jamaat, will operate from a position of strategic distance.Joy succinctly summarised the political outlook, who believed, "Relations between the governments of Bangladesh and India will not improve anytime soon for various reasons."India’s policy response should combine active diplomacy, calibrated development engagement, rapid contingency planning for connectivity, and deeper investments in people-to-people ties — especially among students and youth who will shape Bangladesh’s political future.It must rapidly recalibrate its foreign policy, moving beyond its decades-long reliance on the AL to engage constructively with the new nationalist and religious forces.A failure to adapt risks the unravelling of security gains in India's Northeast and the opening of a significant security vacuum in South Asia, allowing regional rivals like China and Pakistan to increase their influence over a nation that is both a strategic partner and a critical border state.Also, it is interesting to note that the sheer unpredictability of the 18% undecided vote means the political pendulum could swing toward a moderate-nationalist government or one with a powerful Islamist core, but in either case, the relationship with New Delhi will be more transactional, more challenging, and far less secure than at any point in the last fifteen years.Despite the political storms, Dr Rehan noted that a large number of people remain “always grateful to India for independence support,” and recognise that for “business, tourism, medical tourism, education, cultural exchanges, etc., there is no best option other than India-Bangladesh friendly relationship.”This enduring logic is rooted in a shared cultural DNA, which celebrates common heroes like ‘Gurudev’ Rabindranath Tagore and Kazi Nazrul Islam, whose works remain foundational to both nations.He added that ‘India-Bangladesh relationships should be very friendly and supportive... continual cultural and educational ties are very important positive factor between two countries to balance political change.”This enduring cultural and economic logic offers the strongest hope for New Delhi to rebuild trust in a post-Hasina era.Joy also echoed this optimism, adding that with large populations of young people in both nations, "Cultural and historical ties can create a beautiful future for both nations. Instead of being distracted by online influencers, young people should study and explore our historical connections and engagements.”If Delhi wants continuity, it must help deliver stability and visible benefits that ordinary Bangladeshis can recognise as mutual gains; if Dhaka chooses a different path, India will have to adapt — fast and smart — to preserve its strategic and economic interests in a rapidly changing neighbourhood.
Article Summary: Bangladesh is India's largest trading partner in South Asia, with bilateral trade exceeding $15 billion. It is a massive market for Indian exports, machinery, and raw materials, and a critical source of revenue through services and medical tourism. It provides the only viable transit route, via road, rail, and inland waterways, to India's landlocked Northeast region, bypassing the narrow and vulnerable Siliguri Corridor.

Article Title: Myanmar: Drug production booming amid civil war
Article Text:
Representative image (AI-generated)

Chinese cartels protected in the Golden Triangle

Meth production spurred by civil war

Drug-related crisis 'rapidly expanding'

Farmers and fighters dependent on drug sales

Myanmar heroin found in Africa, Europe





New data on opium and methamphetamine production in Myanmar from the United Nations puts the war-torn country at the epicenter of Asia's multi-billion-dollar illicit drug trade.Opium poppy cultivation rose 17% to over 53,000 hectares (131,000 acres) over the past year, the most in a decade, according to the latest opium survey of Myanmar by the UN Office on Drugs and Crime (UNDOC), published this week.Most notably, Myanmar is still the world's top opium producer. The country claimed that spot from Afghanistan in 2023, two years after the Taliban seized control of the country and eradicated the vast majority of its poppy fields.Data published by the UNODC earlier this year also show methamphetamine seizures across East and Southeast Asia in 2024 hitting a record 236 tons.Most of the drug is believed to be produced in Myanmar. According to the UN, the combination of rising seizures and falling street prices suggest that production inside Myanmar continues to grow."I wouldn't really say Myanmar as a country is a supplier, but there [are] criminal groups that are engaging in producing and trafficking this meth and heroin," Inshik Sim, the UNODC's illicit drugs research officer for the Asia Pacific region, told DW.Myanmar has been a major drug producer for decades, partly due to its geography. The nation, once known as Burma, incorporates one corner of the infamous Golden Triangle, where its rugged, crime-infested borderlands in the east meet Laos and Thailand.In Myanmar's Shan state, criminal cartels have set up under the protection of warlords who rule over enclaves where the government has little to no sway. Most of the drug cartels now based there have moved in from China.The chaotic civil war triggered by a 2021 military coup has created favorable conditions for the growth of Myanmar's drug trade, according to the UN. The country's official economy has collapsed, law enforcement has deteriorated, and warlords needed more money to fund their private armies."Because of the conflict, there is some need for people to raise money, whether it's armed groups or farmers, because the conflict disrupts the economy…. And I think opium poppy cultivation is one area that we can see," said Sim.Methamphetamine production was on the rise well before the coup, but, according to Sim, the civil war has likely boosted this trend as well.Thailand has borne the brunt of drug boom happening across its border with Myanmar. Last year, Thai officials seized massive amounts of Myanmar methamphetamine, including a record 1 billion meth tablets."These numbers are a clear warning that the drug problem is not only ongoing but expanding now rapidly," said Thanapon Thanikkun, head of intelligence at Thailand's Office of the Narcotics Control Board.He warned that the traffickers are exploiting Thailand's well-developed transport network to ship their product on land, air and sea, while also leaving a growing drug use problem in their wake.The UNODC confirms meth use in on the rise in Thailand and much of Southeast Asia.For the armed groups supplying this regional demand from Myanmar, selling drugs is a quick way of arming up, said Khun Oo, vice chair of the Pa-O Youth Organization, a non-government group tackling social issues across the Shan state. The Pa-O are one of the state's main ethnic groups."They [armed groups] need guns, they need … human resources and money, so this is the way that they can get it, from the drug trafficking," he said.Unlike methamphetamine, which can be churned out of small labs in huge volumes by a few people, opium production also puts many farmers to work.Poppy has long been a go-to cash crop in Myanmar during hard times. Khun Oo says the civil war has made it much harder for farmers to get their usual crops to market, whereas the drug traffickers who buy opium come to them."In the past, they still could do farming [of] other crops," he said, but now, "they have no options" except growing opium.Khun Oo said the traffickers are also paying farmers up to $500 (€429) for about a kilogram of raw opium in some areas, at least twice what they paid before the coup, making poppy all the more attractive.Products from Myanmar's poppy fields and meth labs travel far and wide across the region and the world.After pouring out of Myanmar into Laos and Thailand, they cascade across the rest of Southeast Asia, and from there may be sold at premium prices in countries like Japan and Australia.Last year, the Australian Federal Police estimated that as much as 70% of the crystal methamphetamine consumed the country came from Myanmar.Sim said China is probably still the main market for Myanmar's heroin. The latest drug seizures, however, suggest the traffickers are now looking westward as well.The UNODC notes a spate of recent meth and heroin seizures over in northeastern India, which also shares a border with Myanmar.Additionally, a string of relatively small but unusual seizures of Myanmar heroin in Nigeria and parts of Europe, by way of Thailand, may indicate that Myanmar cartels are seeking to expand their markets onto new continents."We didn't really see this kind of heroin trafficking flow from this region to others, because the traditional markets of heroin coming out of the Golden Triangle is basically East and Southeast Asia and parts of Oceania. However, we see that more westward flow happens as well," said Sim.
Article Summary: Opium poppy cultivation rose 17% to over 53,000 hectares (131,000 acres) over the past year, according to the latest opium survey of Myanmar. Data published by the UNODC earlier this year also show methamphetamine seizures across East and Southeast Asia in 2024 hitting a record 236 tons. Myanmar has been a major drug producer for decades, partly due to its geography.

Article Title: Cyclone Ditwah: Sri Lanka issues fresh landslide alerts as heavy rains batter island; death toll 618
Article Text:
Photo credit: AP

IMD Issues Red Alert as Cyclone Ditwah Approaches TN; Sri Lanka Deaths Exceed 80





Sri Lankan authorities on Sunday issued fresh landslide warnings as persistent rains battered regions already devastated by Cyclone Ditwah, intensifying what officials describe as the island’s worst natural disaster in decades. At least 618 people are reported dead, with many still missing as rescue teams struggle to reach isolated communities.A chain of tropical storms and monsoonal downpours has cut a destructive path across Southeast and South Asia over the past two weeks. The storms have triggered landslides, flooded wide stretches of land, and severed access to remote settlements from Sumatra’s rainforests to Sri Lanka’s hill country. Across Sri Lanka, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand and Vietnam, at least 1,812 people have died in the unfolding regional crisis, AFP reported.In Sri Lanka alone, more than two million people nearly 10 per cent of the population have been affected. The Disaster Management Centre (DMC) warned that continuing monsoon storms were making hillsides increasingly unstable, particularly in the central mountains and north-western midlands.Helicopters and fixed-wing aircraft were deployed to supply communities cut off by landslides, while the Sri Lanka Air Force confirmed it had received a planeload of relief supplies from Myanmar.Authorities have reported 618 deaths and 209 people unaccounted for, with the central tea-growing region suffering the highest number of casualties. The count of people in state-run shelters has fallen to 100,000 from a peak of 225,000 as waters recede. According to the DMC, nearly 75,000 homes were damaged, including almost 5,000 completely destroyed.The Sri Lankan government on Friday announced a major compensation plan enabling survivors to purchase land in safer zones and rebuild homes. Additional assistance will cover school supplies, household essentials and rent for families not accommodated by the state. AFP reported that a compensation of one million rupees will be offered for each person killed or permanently disabled.According to the UN news, Cyclone Ditwah made landfall on November 28 before looping back over the Bay of Bengal, unleashing some of the worst flooding Sri Lanka has experienced since the early 2000s. The worst-affected districts include Gampaha, Colombo, Puttalam and Mannar, along with Trincomalee and Batticaloa, while lethal landslides in the central hill country have ravaged Kandy, Badulla and Matale.
Article Summary: Sri Lankan authorities issue fresh landslide warnings as persistent rains battered regions already devastated by Cyclone Ditwah. At least 618 people are reported dead, with many still missing as rescue teams struggle to reach isolated communities. A chain of tropical storms and monsoonal downpours has cut a destructive path across Southeast and South Asia over the past two weeks.

Article Title: Afghan–Pakistan border clash: Four civilians, 1 soldier killed amid ceasefire; artillery hits homes near Chaman–Spin Boldak
Article Text:
Photo credit- ANI

Afghanistan FM Muttaqi Defends India Ties, Slams Pakistan Over Deoband Row And Shifting Accusations





Four civilians and a soldier were killed in overnight shelling and gunfire along the Pakistan–Afghanistan border, Afghan officials said on Saturday, marking the latest outbreak of violence between the two countries despite a ceasefire agreement reached after deadly clashes in October.Five other civilians were wounded on the Afghan side, government spokesman Hamdullah Fitrat said in a video statement. A hospital in the Pakistani town of Chaman reported three people with minor injuries following the exchange.Both sides accused each other of firing first near the busy Chaman–Spin Boldak crossing in southern Afghanistan. Taliban spokesman Zabihullah Mujahid said on X that Pakistan “started attacking Afghanistan in Kandahar, Spin Boldak district, and the forces of the Islamic Emirate were forced to respond.” Pakistan prime minister’s spokesman Mosharraf Zaidi alleged that “the Afghan Taliban regime resorted to unprovoked firing” along the border.Local Afghan officials said “light and heavy artillery” was used, with mortar shells striking civilian homes. Residents told AFP that firing began around 10:30 pm and escalated rapidly. One resident described mortars hitting houses after tank fire, while another said his brother was killed when trying to reach a different room during the shelling.People on the Pakistan side said families took shelter indoors as mortar rounds landed near homes.Tensions have surged since the Taliban returned to power in 2021, with Islamabad accusing Kabul of harbouring militant groups, including the Pakistani Taliban (TTP), responsible for attacks inside Pakistan. Kabul denies the allegations. More than 70 people were killed in October clashes before Qatar and Turkey brokered a ceasefire. Talks in Doha and Istanbul since then have failed to produce a lasting settlement, and the border remains closed.Pakistan recently announced it would partially reopen the frontier at Chaman for United Nations aid deliveries. Pakistan’s spokesman Zaidi told AFP the latest clash would “have no impact on that decision,” adding that humanitarian access would continue separately.
Article Summary: Four civilians and a soldier were killed in overnight shelling and gunfire along the Pakistan–Afghanistan border. Five other civilians were wounded on the Afghan side, government spokesman Hamdullah Fitrat said. A hospital in the Pakistani town of Chaman reported three people with minor injuries following the exchange.

Article Title: Khaleda Zia to be flown to London: Air ambulance approved for critically ill ex-Bangladesh PM; transfer likely by Friday
Article Text:
Ex-Bangladesh PM Khaleda Zia (File photo)





A medical board overseeing critically ill former Bangladesh prime minister Khaleda Zia has determined to send her to London for specialist treatment, according to her personal physician AZM Zahid Hossain.According to PTI, Zia, aged 80 and the Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP) chairperson, is scheduled for transfer via air ambulance to London either late Thursday night or early Friday. Her elder son and acting BNP chief Tarique Rahman resides in London.Following a chest infection affecting her heart and lungs, Zia was hospitalised on November 23. She was moved to the coronary care unit (CCU) four days later due to deteriorating health complications."The medical board has unanimously decided that she will be taken to London via the Qatar Royal Air Ambulance, either after midnight tonight or early tomorrow morning," Hossain announced outside the hospital.Whilst Hossain, a BNP standing committee member, refrained from detailed comments about Zia's current condition.At Tuesday's briefing, he had noted her positive response to treatment. The decision for urgent transfer was made by an expanded medical board, including recently arrived specialists from China and the United Kingdom.The BNP released a list of 14 accompanying individuals, including Syeda Shameela Rahman, widow of Zia's younger son Arafat Rahman, six doctors, party adviser Enamul Haque Chowdhury, two Special Security Force (SSF) agents from Muhammad Yunus' interim government, and personal assistants.Qatar offered their air ambulance service whilst military and air force helicopters conducted rooftop landing tests at the hospital. A helicopter transfer is expected from hospital to airport.A Chinese medical team of four specialists arrived Wednesday night, joining a UK medical group led by Dr Richard Buell. This marked the second Chinese delegation, following an advance team's arrival on December 1.Interim government leader Muhammad Yunus visited Wednesday, following visits from military service chiefs. Family members present include her younger brother Shamim Iskandar, his wife Kaniz Fatema, and Sharmila Rahman.Tarique Rahman wrote on Facebook: "In this time of crisis, like any child, I too long for the comforting touch of my mother.""But unlike others, to make a unilateral decision in this regard is not in my hands alone nor solely within my control. The sensitivity of this matter also limits the scope for detailed explanation," he stated.Rahman has resided in London since 2008, previously facing various legal charges. In 2024, Yunus' government withdrew these cases, with courts issuing revised acquittals.Government advisers have assured his safe return. Foreign adviser Touhid Hossain confirmed readiness to process travel documents, though no requests had been received through Wednesday evening.Nationwide prayer gatherings are being held across Bangladesh, including Dhaka, Jhenaidah, Sunamganj, Bagerhat, Cumilla, Chuadanga and Munshiganj, for Zia's recovery.
Article Summary: Former Bangladesh PM Khaleda Zia to be flown to London for specialist treatment. Zia, 80, was hospitalised on November 23 with a chest infection. She was moved to the coronary care unit four days later due to deteriorating health complications.

Article Title: Sri Lanka cyclone tragedy exposes government failures
Article Text:
Source: AP

IMD Issues Red Alert as Cyclone Ditwah Approaches TN; Sri Lanka Deaths Exceed 80

Thousands trapped, isolated

Early warnings wasted

Rescue teams stretched 'beyond capacity'



Opposition blames government for loss of life



Too few alerts in Tamil language







Days after Cyclone Ditwah tore through Sri Lanka, over 1.46 million people across all 25 of the nation's districts remain affected by the island's worst flooding disaster in two decades.According to the government's Disaster Management Center, the official death toll stands at 410, with 336 people still missing. More than 64,000 people from 407,000 affected families are sheltering in nearly 1,450 government-run safety centers across the country.Multiple countries have responded to Sri Lanka's appeal for assistance with India leading the charge, followed by pledges from the UK, China, Australia, and Nepal. Sri Lankan President Anura Kumara Dissanayake has also declared a state of emergency to deal with the aftermath of the cyclone.Despite his declaration and the promise of international aid, however, the Sri Lankan public seems increasingly frustrated with the state's response. Authorities appear to be overwhelmed with rescue demands and are struggling to communicate in a timely manner as critics point out the absence of a unified relief-and-rescue system.Paikiasothy Saravanamuttu, executive director of the Colombo-based Centre for Policy Alternatives, accuses the Sri Lankan government of failing to heed warning signals and allowing the calamity to spiral beyond human control."The government has not come off well in its handling of the crisis and should have called Parliament to convene urgently to review and strengthen disaster management policies," Saravanamuttu told DW.According to Saravanamuttu, "this disaster reveals significant gaps in preparedness and response mechanisms" and the existing frameworks need to be evaluated to "prevent future failures."While Ditwah made landfall in Sri Lanka on November 28, some voices point out that warning signals were present as early as two weeks before. Experts say that the loss of life was exacerbated by the government's failure to act in a timely manner."Unlike tsunamis, hydrometeorological hazards like cyclones arrive with sufficient notice of several days to take precautions. As early as November 12, Sri Lanka's department of meteorology had publicly flagged the prospect of extreme rainfall later in the month. That should have triggered a process of preparations across the government at central, provincial, and local levels," Nalaka Gunawardene, a science writer from Colombo, told DW."Apparently, that did not happen, and an official response has mostly been reactive when Cyclone Ditwah was imminent or after it made landfall," added Gunawardene."The entire disaster management structure – from policymakers to state officials – should be held accountable for cascading failures that made a bad disaster much worse."Kishali Pinto-Jayawardena, a public interest advocate and legal columnist, agrees that the aftermath is "particularly horrendous as the deadly impact of the cyclone was not realized until it was far too late."She told DW that the governments should have "the ability and the competence to take critical decisions" in times of emergency."Sentimental outpouring by politicians lauding the people for 'coming together' in times of crisis does not substitute for that duty," she added.Sivanathan Navindra, a former Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) member, who has been involved in political activities post-conflict, said the cyclone has damaged roads and communication lines in northern Sri Lanka."The situation in northern Mannar, Mullaitivu, Vavuniya, and Kilinochchi districts is extremely severe. Mullaitivu has experienced a total power outage with telecommunication towers down, leaving residents without phone or internet access," Navindra told DW from Jaffna."Road closures have effectively cut off the northern province, with travel between Vavuniya, Mullaitivu, Kilinochchi and Jaffna impossible," he said.Chathuranga Abeysinghe, deputy minister of Industry and Entrepreneurship Development, warned that rising water levels will make evacuation "extremely difficult." He urged residents along the Kelaniya River and flood-prone areas to leave."There have been immense hardships caused by Cyclone Ditwah, but the president has constituted task forces to study the impact and organize relief. It will take a while for rebuilding," Abeysinghe told DW."We had initial difficulty in predicting the cyclone's course" Abeysinghe said, noting that significant rainfall expected was many different areas which "stretched rescue teams beyond capacity to reach everyone in need."Abeysinghe also pointed out that the government was working on a war-footing to reach vulnerable populations that had been cut off.Government critics, however, remain unconvinced by the official narrative. Opposition party Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) recently pledged to launch legal action against the government.SJB lawmaker and spokesperson S M Marikkar compared the severity of the disaster to the Easter Sunday suicide attacks which killed nearly 270 people in 2019, and the more recent economic collapse under the powerful Rajapaksa family."Similar to the criminal case filed against the Rajapaksas for bankrupting the nation, we will file a case against the current government, as they are responsible for every citizen that died in the disaster," Marikkar told the media on Monday.Despite some relief materials being delivered and emergency teams arriving to certain affected locations, many communities still lack clarity on when full help will arrive and when normalcy can be restored. A notable communication obstacle, according to Colombo-based disinformation expert and analyst Sanjana Hattotuwa, is the choice of languages officials use for disaster communications.The nation recognizes both the majority language of Sinhala and the smaller Tamil language as official, with English — a remnant of the British colonial period — also spoken to varying degrees by nearly a quarter of its population."My research showed key updates were in Sinhala only, and sometimes mirrored in English, but rarely, if ever in Tamil. State television and radio did not communicate the risks, and threats, mirroring what was evident on social media," Hattotuwa told DW."This contributed to [an] information vacuum in critical hours, impacting preparedness and community responses," he said. "If information was available in a more effective and timely manner, lives now lost may have been saved."
Article Summary: Cyclone Ditwah has left over 1.46 million people in Sri Lanka affected by flooding. The official death toll stands at 410, with 336 people still missing. More than 64,000 people from 407,000 affected families are sheltering in nearly 1,450 government-run safety centers.
